name: NPR
text:
Americans have long made up much of chef J.P. McMahon’s clientele in Ireland — but now he says he gets hate emails for serving them.  

"On the door of one restaurant I have read the words: 'No British or American Tourists.' "
https://t.co/ZojFxMIx9p

name: NPR
text:
On Thursday morning, Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine tested positive for the coronavirus.
By that evening, he tested negative.

Our colleagues at @WOSUnews break down how 2 tests on the same day could yield such different results.
https://t.co/4YxR5iZtz1

name: NPR
text: @nprhealth also has this handy guide to the three types of coronavirus tests: https://t.co/8nwSnvYipA

name: NPR
text:
The FDA approved nasal spray Spravato for suicidal patients with major depression.

The drug's approval comes as many people are experiencing stress and anxiety related to the pandemic.
https://t.co/Ggt2w0K3kH

name: NPR
text:
Attorney General William Barr says he will not take any action to influence the upcoming election.

But Justice Department veterans have doubts as a probe apparently focused on the Obama administration looms in the background. 
https://t.co/Bm3RDHrqvB

name: NPR
text:
Delta has banned 100 anti-maskers from taking their flights — and even gone a step further by adding them to a "no fly" list.

Despite outrage from some consumers, legal experts say it's within the airline's scope of rights. 
https://t.co/QznkBdANzq

name: NPR
text:
Union membership has declined steadily over the last 40 years, but the brutal unemployment situation is revealing how poorly many American workers are paid — and how few protections they have.
https://t.co/2B0fyk3u8N

name: NPR
text: Black people comprise 40% of the U.S. homeless population, despite being only 13% of the general public. To many advocates, chronic homelessness is just one more symptom of systemic racism. @wamu885 https://t.co/gGmaT4IzsD

name: NPR
text:
The Starz drama "P-Valley" is set in a Black strip club in the Mississippi Delta. The show is about their labor, but also about a wide variety of stories about power, money, and a community's identity.
https://t.co/xDHbbriNKV

name: NPR
text:
Chief Justice Bernette Johnson compared Fair Wayne Bryant's life sentence for stealing a pair of hedge clippers to "Pig Laws" in the years after Reconstruction that "were largely designed to re-enslave African Americans."
https://t.co/WOsaEUYafh

name: NPR
text:
A proposed rule that could allow homeless shelters to turn away transgender people based on physical appearance is the Trump administration’s latest attack against trans rights. 

More details from @hereandnow ⤵️ 
https://t.co/yROEwQfjNg

name: NPR
text: The long-term physical and mental health toll on COVID-19 survivors remains largely unknown, since the virus is so new. But for the first COVID patient to get a double lung transplant, it means 68 pills a day -- and daily panic attacks. @ILNewsroom https://t.co/2mtD2YYhJx

name: NPR
text: While the global economy spirals downward, Catan Inc. says sales of its board game skyrocketed by 144% for the first 5 months of this year. https://t.co/8pETPaoaA0

name: NPR
text:
Since 1926, the Quander family has gathered each year to honor their history — one that traces back to Nancy Carter Quander, the family matriarch who was formerly enslaved by George Washington.

This year marks the first time they won't do so. @StoryCorps https://t.co/qeU2Lc6rBv

name: NPR
text:
We need water to live. But with rising seas and so many lacking clean water — water is in crisis and so are we. 

On this @TEDRadioHour, speakers explore ideas around restoring our relationship with water. https://t.co/Ook4NLTeWD

name: NPR
text:
Scientists, artists, thinkers, activists and journalists gather for meals and discuss societal problems in the new show, "Pan y Circo."

"The table is a place where at least we can remind ourselves that we can share the food," says host Diego Luna.
 https://t.co/Tr4WeaRgXV

name: NPR
text:
The "Dirty South" or "Southern Hip Hop" wasn't necessarily a thing — let alone a movement — until two things happen simultaneously:

1) Artists embrace their Southern identities
2) They begin working together
https://t.co/YuKFUjXv4D

name: NPR
text:
When house cats kill small birds and mammals, their impact is concentrated in a small area — having a bigger effect than wild predators do, a tracking study of more than 900 house cats shows. #InternationalCatDay
https://t.co/B10xaPPNjf

name: NPR
text:
While some felines can self-regulate when it comes to food, most indoor cats need help keeping the pounds off. 

It's estimated that more than half of the indoor cats in the U.S. are overweight. https://t.co/6evEZv7A5b

name: NPR
text: For many Yazidi women, the trauma of being enslaved, raped and beaten by ISIS fighters didn’t end when they were freed. Here’s one survivor’s story. https://t.co/wb9l6tTlKp

name: NPR
text:
Exclusive: TikTok plans to sue the Trump administration, arguing that President Trump's executive order banning the app from the U.S. is unconstitutional because it failed to give the company a chance to respond.
https://t.co/BM0Ee7Bf2K

name: NPR
text:
Virginia's Supreme Court has granted a request from Gov. Ralph Northam to temporarily stop evictions proceedings. The moratorium extends protections for tenants who can't pay their rent through September 7.
https://t.co/jvOpiWJ2aG

name: NPR
text:
Satellite images used to be restricted to a handful of governments. Now anyone can get them, creating a new world of possibilities for human rights groups, environmentalists and researchers who monitor nuclear programs.
https://t.co/NOxzK69FxD

name: NPR
text:
2 out of 3 regular churchgoers feel it's now safe to resume in-person worship, a new survey finds.

Still, an overwhelming majority of U.S. adults say houses of worship should be subject to the same restrictions on public gatherings as other institutions. https://t.co/DQlHnKePNA
